name: The Four Kerubim (Tarot Tradition)
description: The Four Kerubim as depicted in Tarot tradition, deriving from the biblical cherubim of Ezekiel and Revelation, representing the four Evangelists and four fixed zodiacal signs.
symbolism: The traditional Sphinx combines all four Kerubim: the body of a bull, the paws of a lion, the wings of an eagle, and the head of a human. This composite creature represents the integration of all four elements and the mastery required to solve the riddle of existence. The Sphinx asks, "What walks on four legs in the morning, two at noon, and three in the evening?" The answer‚Äî humanity‚Äîpoints to the human (Aquarius) as the synthesizing principle that understands all stages of manifestation.

christian.overview: The Four Kerubim as they appear in Tarot tradition (particularly the World and Wheel of Fortune cards) derive directly from biblical cherubim, especially Ezekiel 1 and Revelation 4. This represents Christianity's enduring influence on Western esoteric symbolism.

biblicalOrigin.ezekielVision: Ezekiel 1:5-14 describes the four living creatures with faces of man, lion, ox, and eagle - the direct source for Tarot kerubim iconography.
biblicalOrigin.revelationContinuity: Revelation 4:6-8 continues the tradition, placing the four living creatures around God's throne in perpetual worship.
biblicalOrigin.gospelConnection: The Church's association of these four faces with the four Evangelists (Matthew-Man, Mark-Lion, Luke-Ox, John-Eagle) provides the theological framework adopted by Tarot.

tarotDevelopment.historicalContext: Tarot emerged in 15th century Christian Europe and incorporated traditional Christian symbolism, including the cherubim.
tarotDevelopment.worldCard: The World (XXI) typically shows the dancing figure surrounded by the four kerubim, representing cosmic completion and the four fixed signs of the zodiac as well as the four Gospels.
tarotDevelopment.wheelOfFortune: The Wheel of Fortune (X) often includes the four kerubim reading books (the Gospels), representing eternal wisdom overseeing temporal change.

christianEvaluation.legitimateRoots: The kerubim imagery in Tarot preserves authentic Christian symbolism, even when used in non-Christian contexts.
christianEvaluation.theologicalCaution: While the imagery is biblically grounded, its use in divination diverges from the creatures' biblical function as worshippers and guardians.
christianEvaluation.reclamationPotential: Some Christian interpreters see in Tarot kerubim an opportunity to reclaim profound biblical symbols for their original purpose.

evangelistCorrespondence.lion: Mark - Christ's royal power and resurrection
evangelistCorrespondence.eagle: John - Christ's divine nature and ascension

christian.typologicalReading: The four living creatures represent the fullness of creation worshipping its Creator. Their presence in both biblical vision and Tarot imagery witnesses to the enduring power of Christian symbolism in Western culture.
scholarlyReferences: Decker, Ronald, Thierry Depaulis, and Michael Dummett. A Wicked Pack of Cards: Origins of the Occult Tarot. New York: St. Martin's Press, 1996.
Place, Robert M. The Tarot: History, Symbolism, and Divination. New York: Tarcher, 2005.
Block, Daniel I. The Book of Ezekiel. Grand Rapids: Eerdmans, 1997.
